title: What to Do if Your Toilet Fill Valve is Leaking

steps.title: You can find the supply valve behind your toilet.
steps.content: You can find the supply valve behind your toilet. To turn off the water supply, Schuelke recommends turning the valve clockwise until it won’t spin any further. Then, give it a little extra push to the right. [1] X Expert Source James Schuelke Professional Plumber Expert Interview. 1 October 2019. That way, you’ll stay dry when you eventually disconnect the fill valve from your toilet. [2] X Research source If the supply valve is stuck, you can always turn off the water intake to your home, but that prevents water from reaching all of your fixtures.

steps.title: Water will leak around the valve if the tank is full.
steps.content: Water will leak around the valve if the tank is full. Schuelke says that the easiest way to remove the water is to flush your toilet like normal to get all of the remaining water out of the tank so you can easily access the valve inside. [3] X Expert Source James Schuelke Professional Plumber Expert Interview. 1 October 2019. If there’s still water in the bottom of your tank, use an old towel or a shop vac to get rid of it. Otherwise, it will spill out on the floor when you remove your fill valve. [4] X Research source

steps.title: It should easily unscrew by hand or with a wrench.
steps.content: It should easily unscrew by hand or with a wrench. Lay a towel out on the floor underneath the hose to catch any water that might still spill out. Follow the supply hose up to the bottom of the toilet tank and spin the nut counter-clockwise to loosen it completely. Set the hose aside for now so it’s out of your way. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Find the nut on the bottom of the toilet’s tank.
steps.content: Find the nut on the bottom of the toilet’s tank. Take the lid off of your toilet and hold the top of the flush valve with your hand. Secure a wrench around the plastic nut connected to the bottom of the toilet tank. Hold the flush valve tightly and turn the nut counter-clockwise to loosen it. Once it’s loose, take it off by hand. After that, you can simply pull the fill valve straight out from the tank. [6] X Research source When you remove the fill valve completely, a little more water could spill out onto the floor, so keep it dry with a towel.

steps.title: You can find fill valves at any hardware store.
steps.content: You can find fill valves at any hardware store. Fill valves are universal and adjustable, so they work no matter what toilet you have. If you want to match the fill valve that you already have, bring it with you to the hardware store so you can buy the same one. [7] X Research source Fill valves usually only cost around $10–15 USD. If you’re not sure whether the fill valve is the problem, Balkan recommends replacing the whole assembly inside the toilet. He says, “It only costs around $20 or $30, and it could save you hours trying to figure out the problem.” [8] X Expert Source David Balkan Professional Plumber & CEO of Balkan Sewer & Water Main Expert Interview. 29 April 2021.

steps.title: This seals any gaps between the valve and the hole in the tank.
steps.content: This seals any gaps between the valve and the hole in the tank. Your new fill valve will come with a circular rubber gasket that has tapered sides. Position the gasket on the threaded end of the fill valve so the narrow end of the gasket points down and push it on as far as it will go. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Your new valve will fit perfectly where the old one was.
steps.content: Your new valve will fit perfectly where the old one was. Feed the threaded end of the new fill valve into the hole so it pokes out from the bottom of your toilet. Find the plastic nut that came with your new fill valve and screw it clockwise onto the threading. Tighten the nut by hand up against the base of the toilet before giving it one more quarter-turn with your wrench. [10] X Research source Be careful not to overtighten the plastic nut since you could easily strip or break it.

steps.title: This tube sprays water into your toilet bowl to refill it.
steps.content: This tube sprays water into your toilet bowl to refill it. The refill tube is the small plastic tubing sticking out from the side of the fill valve. Use the clip on the tube to attach it to the top of the overflow pipe. Make sure the tube points down inside the pipe so it works properly. [11] X Research source

steps.title: The supply pipe connects directly to the bottom of the valve.
steps.content: The supply pipe connects directly to the bottom of the valve. Position the end of the hose on the fill valve’s threading underneath your toilet. Turn the end of the supply hose clockwise by hand until it’s tight on the valve. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Refill the tank to check for leaks.
steps.content: Refill the tank to check for leaks. To refill the tank, Schuelke says to turn the supply valve handle counter-clockwise so the water turns back on and refills the tank. [13] X Expert Source James Schuelke Professional Plumber Expert Interview. 1 October 2019. If you notice any water spraying or leaking from the hose, then it’s not tight enough. Try giving it another quarter-turn to help secure it. [14] X Research source

steps.title: The water level should be 1–1 1⁄2 in (2.5–3.8 cm) below the overflow pipe.
steps.content: The water level should be 1– 1 1 ⁄ 2 in (2.5–3.8 cm) below the overflow pipe. If the water level is still too high and leaking into the pipe, find the adjustment screw on top of the fill valve and turn it counter-clockwise to lower it back down. [15] X Research source
